title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #65** connects edge density to cycle structure.

Given a graph G with n vertices and kn edges, let a₁ < a₂ < ... be the distinct cycle lengths. Two questions:
1. Is Σ 1/aᵢ ≫ log k? (PROVED by GKS 1984)
2. Is this sum minimized when G is complete bipartite? (OPEN)

The sum Σ 1/aᵢ measures 'cycle variety' with shorter cycles weighted more heavily.
mathContext: For G = (V, E) with |V| = n and |E| = kn, the edge density k relates to average degree 2k. Dense graphs should have diverse cycle lengths.

title: Background on Cycle Variety
content:
The **cycle variety sum** Σ 1/aᵢ captures how 'spread out' the cycle lengths are.

- Short cycles (length 3, 4, 5) contribute large terms (1/3, 1/4, 1/5)
- Long cycles contribute negligibly
- Dense graphs (high k) force more edge connectivity, creating more cycles

The log k lower bound says: doubling edge density roughly adds 1 to the sum.
mathContext: Average degree 2k means most vertices have many neighbors. The pigeonhole principle forces short paths to close into cycles.

title: Cyclic Successor
content:
**Fin.succMod** defines the cyclic successor: i ↦ (i+1) mod k.

This is essential for defining cycles: vertex i connects to vertex (i+1) mod k, so vertex k-1 wraps back to vertex 0, closing the cycle.
mathContext: For a k-cycle, vertices are labeled 0, 1, ..., k-1 with edges i ~ (i+1) mod k. This requires modular arithmetic on Fin k.

title: Cycle Length Detection
content:
**ContainsCycleLength G k** holds when G contains a k-cycle.

Formally: there exist k ≥ 3 distinct vertices v₀, v₁, ..., vₖ₋₁ such that each vᵢ is adjacent to v₍ᵢ₊₁₎ ₘₒₖ k.

**CycleLengthSet G** collects all such k into a set.
mathContext: The injectivity requirement ensures the vertices are distinct (no repeated vertices). The cycle must have length ≥ 3 (triangles and larger).

title: Cycle Length Finset
content:
**cycleLengthFinset G** computes the finite set of cycle lengths in G.

For a graph on n vertices, cycle lengths are bounded by n (you can't have a cycle longer than the number of vertices). So we filter the range [0, n] for valid cycle lengths.

This uses classical decidability since cycle detection is generally undecidable without explicit algorithms.
mathContext: noncomputable because Classical.dec provides decidability without computation. In practice, cycle detection is polynomial-time.

title: Edge Density and Reciprocal Sum
content:
**edgeDensity G** = |E| / |V| is the ratio of edges to vertices.

**cycleLengthReciprocalSum G** = Σ_{k ∈ cycles} 1/k measures cycle variety.

These are the two key quantities in the problem: we want to show the reciprocal sum grows at least logarithmically with edge density.
mathContext: Edge density k means average degree 2k. The reciprocal sum is essentially a weighted count of cycle lengths, with short cycles weighted more.

title: Gyárfás-Komlós-Szemerédi Theorem (1984)
content:
**The GKS Theorem**: For any graph G with n vertices and kn edges:

Σ 1/aᵢ ≥ c · log(k)

for some absolute constant c > 0.

This resolves the first part of Erdős's question affirmatively. Dense graphs MUST have diverse cycle lengths.
mathContext: The logarithmic bound is tight up to constants. Liu-Montgomery (2020) proved the sharp constant is (1/2 - o(1)).

title: The Open Minimization Question
content:
**Erdos65Question** (OPEN): Is the reciprocal sum minimized by complete bipartite graphs?

For K_{r,s} (the complete bipartite graph), cycle lengths are exactly {4, 6, 8, ..., 2·min(r,s)}.

The conjecture: among all graphs with rs edges on r+s vertices, K_{r,s} has the smallest Σ 1/aᵢ.
mathContext: Complete bipartite graphs avoid odd cycles entirely (no 1/3, 1/5, ... terms). This might minimize the sum, but proving it requires understanding ALL graphs with the same edge count.

title: Complete Bipartite Cycle Structure
content:
**Complete bipartite K_{r,s} cycle lengths**: exactly {4, 6, 8, ..., 2·min(r,s)}.

Key properties:
- Minimum cycle length is 4 (no triangles in bipartite graphs)
- Maximum cycle length is 2·min(r,s)
- All intermediate even lengths are achieved
- No odd cycles exist
mathContext: A cycle in K_{r,s} alternates between the two parts, so it must have even length. The maximum uses all vertices of the smaller part twice.

title: Bipartite Cycle Sum Formula
content:
**bipartiteCycleSum(r, s)** = Σᵢ₌₂^{min(r,s)} 1/(2i) = (1/2) · Σᵢ₌₂^m 1/i

This is half of a partial harmonic sum. For large m = min(r,s):

bipartiteCycleSum ≈ (1/2) · (ln(m) - 1 + γ)

where γ ≈ 0.577 is the Euler-Mascheroni constant.
mathContext: The factor of 1/2 comes from even-only cycle lengths: we sum 1/4 + 1/6 + 1/8 + ... = (1/2)(1/2 + 1/3 + 1/4 + ...).

title: Minimum Degree Forces Short Cycles
content:
**Classical result**: A graph with minimum degree d ≥ 2 contains a cycle of length at most 2d.

**Proof idea**: Take a longest path P = v₀ - v₁ - ... - vₖ. The endpoint vₖ has d neighbors, all on P (else we could extend). By pigeonhole, some neighbor vᵢ has i ≤ 2d, giving a cycle of length k - i ≤ k ≤ 2d.
mathContext: This is a key technique in extremal graph theory: longest paths force short cycles via degree constraints.

title: Kővári-Sós-Turán Theorem
content:
**The KST Theorem** (1954): A K_{r,s}-free graph on n vertices has at most

(1/2)(s-1)^{1/r} · n^{2-1/r} + ((r-1)/2) · n

edges.

This is the **Zarankiewicz problem**: what's the maximum edges avoiding a complete bipartite subgraph?
mathContext: For r = s = 2, this gives the C₄-free bound: at most (1/2)n^{3/2} + n/2 edges. The GKS proof uses similar extremal techniques.

title: Density One Implies Cycles
content:
**Lemma**: A graph with n edges on n vertices contains a cycle.

**Proof**: A forest (acyclic graph) on n vertices has at most n-1 edges. Each tree component with v vertices contributes v-1 edges.

With n edges, the graph has 'extra' edges beyond a spanning forest, so some component must contain a cycle.
mathContext: This is the base case: even k = 1 forces at least one cycle. The GKS theorem shows k ≫ 1 forces many cycle lengths.

title: Bipartite Graphs Have Only Even Cycles
content:
**Classical result**: In a bipartite graph, all cycles have even length.

**Proof**: 2-color the graph (bipartite = 2-colorable). Walking around a cycle, colors alternate: R-B-R-B-...

After k steps, we return to the starting vertex (starting color). This requires k to be even.
mathContext: This is why complete bipartite graphs avoid odd cycle contributions (1/3, 1/5, 1/7, ...) in the reciprocal sum.

title: Odd Cycle Positive Contribution
content:
**Theorem**: An odd cycle of length k ≥ 3 contributes 1/k > 0 to the reciprocal sum.

**Proof**: Uses `positivity` tactic since k ≥ 3 implies k > 0 as a real number.

This is the fully verified theorem in the file - the one actual proof rather than axiom.
mathContext: Odd cycles are exactly what non-bipartite graphs have. Their positive contribution (1/3, 1/5, ...) might make non-bipartite graphs have larger sums than bipartite ones.

title: Summary and Status
content:
**Erdős Problem #65 Status: PARTIALLY SOLVED**

✅ **PROVED** (GKS 1984): Σ 1/aᵢ ≫ log k for graphs with kn edges on n vertices.

❓ **OPEN**: Is K_{r,s} the minimizer among graphs with rs edges on r+s vertices?

**Why K_{r,s} might minimize**:
1. No odd cycles → no 1/3, 1/5, ... terms
2. Consecutive even lengths → no 'gaps' in the sum
3. Maximum structure with minimum variety
mathContext: Liu-Montgomery (2020) proved the sharp bound (1/2 - o(1))log k. The minimization question requires comparing all graphs with the same edge count.
